creditline: The Jane and James Emison Endowment for South Asian and Indian Art
description: squatting male figure with knees splayed apart, head turned slightly toward PL; figure has rounded belly, wide mouth and nose (missing) and high eyebrows; figure holds a bowl in his PR hand, resting on his knee; figure wears a large earspool in his PR ear with a floral motif and a round earring with floral motif in his elongated PL earlobe; figure also wears a beaded necklace and a headdress; small female figure (face and portion of PR arm missing) behind larger figure's PL shoulder; arched element behind large figure's head and shoulders; reddish grey stone; attached to black base
text: This portly dwarf leads the good life. His name is Kubera, and from his elaborate hairdo and fabulous jewelry to his cushy, lotus adorned throne, he radiates wealth and prosperity. In early Indic religions, Kubera was the king of a class of semi-divine nature deities known as yakshas. Later Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain religions incorporated Kubera into their divine pantheon as the god of wealth. His now missing left hand once held a sack of jewels, and two female attendants fanned him with flywhisks.
title: Kubera
